Award.AwardTitle: Tomographic Visualization of Electron-Beam-Driven Plasma Wakefield Accelerators
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plasma acceleration is a cutting-edge technique for accelerating charged particles such as electrons using the electric field associated with a plasma structure, such as an electron plasma wave. The plasma structure is created using either ultra-short laser pulses or particle beams. This technique offers a way to build high performance particle accelerators of much smaller size than conventional accelerator techniques. The goal of this award is visualizing evolving plasma wakefield accelerator structures generated by intense GeV electron bunches. The single-shot visualization and control techniques developed and refined through this research can impact a wide cross section of plasma science. The visualization of electron beam driven wakes will support development of "plasma afterburners", an emerging technology for doubling the energy of conventional linear colliders. These methods will also promote more reliable tabletop plasma-based accelerators, which are useful as compact coherent x-ray sources for biological, chemical, and medical research, injectors for conventional accelerators, and medical accelerators. Finally the proposed research will train a research associate, a Ph.D. student, and an undergraduate from UT-San Antonio, which ranks 4th in the nation in number of undergraduate degrees awarded to Hispanics.

The proposed award will provide the first direct laboratory visualization of electron-beam driven plasma wakes, and will advance new, unique approaches to visualizing rapidly evolving relativistic electron-beam-plasma interactions that the PI pioneered. They will complement, benchmark and validate computer simulations in understanding the physics of electron-beam driven wakes, and in developing strategies to optimize and scale plasma wakefield accelerators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project introduced a new method of visualizing inner workings of a new type of electron accelerator that is thousands of times smaller and less expensive than conventional accelerators.  Since the 1930s, scientists have been building ever bigger and more expensive machines to accelerate charged particles to more than 99% of the speed of light, which Einstein discovered to be the speed limit of the universe.  At such enormous speeds, electrons can probe into nature's deepest subatomic secrets, irradiate cancerous tumors, and generate powerful x-rays that measure the structure of molecules essential to life.  One of America's biggest electron accelerators, a 2-mile-long machine called "SLAC" (which originally stood for "Stanford Linear Accelerator Center") accelerates electrons to 99.99999999% of the speed of light.  The energy carried by such an electron, at 30 giga-electronvolts (GeV), is less than a mosquito uses to flap its wings once, but it's a lot of energy for one electron. 

To stay at the forefront of accelerator science, America will need to accelerate electrons well beyond 30 GeV.  However, to extend SLAC even by a factor of two, to 60 GeV, would require a billion-dollar investment in conventional technology, comparable to the accelerator's original cost, plus the purchase of an additional 2-mile-long tract of prime California real estate.  About a decade ago, a group of accelerator scientists built a laboratory at SLAC called the "Facility for Accelerator Science and Experimental Tests", or "FACET" for short, to investigate an alternative, more compact, and less expensive way to extend SLAC's energy.  At FACET, each SLAC electron bunch is split into two tandem bunches, which are then sent into a meter-long box filled with ionized gas, or plasma (the same state of matter one finds inside fluorescent light bulbs and stars) that is about 1% as dense as air.  The first bunch disturbs the plasma, creating a moving electron density wave, or "wake", much like the wake of a boat plowing through an initially still lake.  The second bunch, appropriately timed, surfs on this wake, gaining energy.  Scientists demonstrated that they could double the energy of at least some of the electrons in the second bunch in this "plasma wakefield accelerator".  With refinements, they were able to increase the energy of nearly all the electrons in the second bunch by about 10 GeV.  They had similar success in accelerating positively-charged electrons, or "positrons", an essential component of a high-energy electron-positron "collider" for elementary particle physics experiments.  This plasma wakefield acceleration took place within one meter, instead of two miles. 

Following up on its initial proof-of-principle success, the FACET project is now preparing for an advanced phase, called "FACET II", which aims to energy-double an entire electron bunch efficiently while maintaining high bunch quality --- i.e. a bunch that can be focused down to a tiny interaction point.  This requires in-situ diagnostics of the inner workings of the plasma wakefield accelerator, which has heretofore been a "black box" visible only indirectly through the virtual reality of computer simulations.  This project developed and demonstrated a technique to visualize the electron-beam-driven plasma wakefield accelerators directly for the first time.  A laser pulse nearly co-propagated through the plasma with the first electron bunch, making about a 1-degree angle with its path, and overlapping its plasma wake throughout the transit.  The plasma wake diffracted the probe laser pulse.  By analyzing its diffraction pattern downstream, after the laser pulse exited the plasma, we were able to reconstruct the plasma wake.  The accompanying figure shows two diffraction patterns, taken from a 20-centimeter long section of the meter-long path.  The first pattern is uniform and straight, indicating that the electron bunch coupled smoothly into the plasma and formed a stable wake structure.  The second pattern is non-uniform and crooked, indicating that the electron-plasma interaction became unstable, like a racecar spinning out of control on a slippery track.

 Our imaging technique has been incorporated into the permanent FACET infrastructure.  In future research we hope to improve our algorithms for reconstructing the wake, introduce additional probe laser pulses to gain a more complete view of the wake, and to study both electron- and positron-driven wakes.  This research will help guide the FACET project toward an optimized plasma-based accelerator architecture that will reduce the size and cost of accelerators used in high-energy physics, x-ray science, medicine and manufacturing.
